p: Zingiberene, the chief component of the Z. officinale essential oil here analyzed, is a monocyclic sesquiterpene hydrocarbon with natural antioxidant and cytotoxic activities: it is capable of protecting against H 2O 2-induced cytotoxicity and oxidative DNA damage in neuronal cells [ 35] as well as inhibiting the growth of lymphocytic cells in a dose-dependent manner [ 36]. Furthermore, high zingiberene content in tomato plants provides resistance against arthropod pests including spider mite ( Tetranychus urticae) and whitefly ( Bemisia tabaci) [ 37, 38]. On the other hand, Î²-sesquiphelladrene, the main isomer of zingiberene and second main compound in the ginger essential oil here analyzed, has antiviral and antifertility effects [ 38] as well as anticancer potential by inducing apoptosis through mitochondrial pathways [ 39].
